titleStmt.title: Tvvo petitions from the agents to ten regiments of horse and foot and of the life-guard, under the conduct of his Excellencie Sir Thomas Fairfax; to the supreame authority of this nation, the Commons assembled in Parliament: in behalfe of themselves and all other the free-born people of England. Presented in their names by the Lord Grey an honest member of the House of Commons together with an agreement of the people grounded upon the principles of common right and freedome, for the Parliaments concurrence thereunto. Also the votes of the House upon the said papers thereunto annexed.

titleStmt.title: Tvvo petitions from the agents to ten regiments of horse and foot and of the life-guard, under the conduct of his Excellencie Sir Thomas Fairfax; to the supreame authority of this nation, the Commons assembled in Parliament: in behalfe of themselves and all other the free-born people of England. Presented in their names by the Lord Grey an honest member of the House of Commons together with an agreement of the people grounded upon the principles of common right and freedome, for the Parliaments concurrence thereunto. Also the votes of the House upon the said papers thereunto annexed.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: TVVO PETITIONS FROM The Agents to ten Regiments of Hor≈øe and foot, and of the Life-Guard, under the Conduct of his Excellencie Sir Thomas Fairfax; To the ≈øupreame Authority of this Nation, the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament: in behalfe of them≈øelves and all other the Free-born People of England.

Pre≈øented in their names by the Lord Grey [an hone≈øt Member of the [Hou≈øe of Commons] together with an Agreement of the people grounded upon the principles of Common Right and Freedome, for the Parliaments concurrence thereunto.
Al≈øo the Votes of the Hou≈øe upon the ≈øaid Papers thereunto annexed.
Printed in the Yeere, 1647.

div.head: To the ≈øupreame Authority of this Nation, the Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled.
The ju≈øt and earne≈øt Petition of tho≈øe who≈øe Names are ≈øub≈øcribed, in behalfe of them≈øelves, and all the Free-born People of England.
div.p: THat the Rights we claime in the Agreement (hereunto annexed) are our own, both by birth and purcha≈øe. That we ≈øee no other meanes (under Heaven) to pre≈øerve tho≈øe Rights unto our ≈øelves, and our deare Fellow-Commoners, then by ≈øo agreeing, and declaring.

That this Agreement ≈øhall (by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) be maintained with the ≈øame re≈øolution of ≈øpirit, and hazard of our lives, wherewith our freedomes were (as we thought) recovered, rather then we will ≈øuffer our ≈øelves by any force or fraud to be deprived of them or any part of them.

That it is equally grievous to us, whether wee be in≈ølaved by King or Lords, but to be in continuall Conferences and Addre≈ø≈øes, offered up by tho≈øe we Tru≈øt, into the hands of ≈øuch, as have manife≈øted their tyrannicall Purpo≈øes towards us, and towards you for our ≈øakes, is a danger we can hold no longer.

We do therefore mo≈øt earne≈øtly be≈øeech you, to joyne with your tryed friends, and naturall Country-men in this AGREEMENT (every way tending to your Weale and Ours) and not with the King nor witt any others, by adventuring againe the price of our bloud upon the un≈øafe and groundle≈ø≈øe Termes of Accommodation with perfidious Enemies.

That your extreamly-long-forbearing to ≈øettle the Peoples peace and liberties upon your own Authority (which indeed is theirs) without any ju≈øt cau≈øe as hinder you, (your Capitall enemy being at your mercy, and a con≈øiderable Army at your commaund) is matter of great jealou≈øie, and hath nece≈ø≈øitated as to betake our ≈øelves to this extroardinary way of remedy.

Re≈øolved, &c.
THat the Matters contained in the≈øe Papers, are de≈øtructive to the Being of Parliaments, and to the Fundamentall Government of the Kingdome.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øing Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p:
Re≈øolved &c.
THat a Letter be ≈øent to the Generall, and the≈øe Papers enclo≈øed, together with the Vote of this Hou≈øe upon them, that he be de≈øired to examine proceedings of this Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the Army, and return an accompt hereof to this Hou≈øe.
Mr. REYNOLDS and Mr. PRIDEAUX are appointed to prepare a Letter to this purpo≈øe.

div.head: The Agreement of the People, &c.
div.p: HAving by our late labours and hazards made it appeare to the world at how high a rate we value our ju≈øt freedom, & God having ≈øo far owned our cau≈øe, as to deliver the Enemies thereof into our hands: We do now head our ≈øelves bound in mutuall duty to each other, to take the be≈øt care we can for the future, to avoid both the danger of returning into a ≈ølavi≈øh condition, and the chargeable remedy of another war: for as it cannot be imagined that ≈øo many of our Country-men would have oppo≈øed us in this quarrel, if they had under≈øtood their own good, ≈øo may we ≈øafely promi≈øe to our ≈øelves, that when our Common Rights and liberties ≈øhall be cleared, their endeavours will be di≈øappointed, that ≈øeeke to make them≈øelves our Ma≈øters ≈øince therefore our former oppre≈ø≈øions, and ≈øcarce yet ended troubles have been occa≈øioned, either by want of frequent Nationall meetings in Councell, or by rendring tho≈øe meetings ineffectuall: We are fully agreed and re≈øolved, to provide that hereafter our Repre≈øentatives be neither left to an uncertainty for the time, nor made u≈øele≈ø≈øe to the ends for which they are intended: In order whereunto we declare,

1. That the people of England being at this day very unequally di≈øtributed by Counties, Cities, and Burroughes for the election of their Deputies in Parliament, ought to be more indifferently proportioned, according to the number of the Inhabitants: the circum≈øtances whereof, for number, place, and manner, are to be ≈øet down before the end of this pre≈øent Parliament. 2. That to prevent the many inconveniences apparently ari≈øing, from the long continuance of the ≈øame per≈øons in authority, this pre≈øent Parliament be di≈ø≈øolved upon the la≈øt day of September, which ≈øhall be in the yeare of our Lord, 1648.

3. That the People do of cour≈øe chu≈øe them≈øelves a Parliament once in two yeares, viz. upon the fir≈øt Thur≈øday in every 2d. March, after the manner as ≈øhall be pre≈øcribed before the end of this Parliament, to begin to ≈øit upon the fir≈øt Thur≈øday in Aprill following at We≈øtmin≈øter, or ≈øuch other place as ≈øhall be appointed from time to time by the preceding Repre≈øen ‚Ä¢ atives; & to continue till the la≈øt day of September, then n ‚Ä¢ xt en≈øuing, and no longer.

4. That the power of this, and all future Repre≈øentatives of this Nation, is inferiour only to theirs who chu≈øe them, and doth extend, without the con≈øent or concurrence of any other per≈øon or per≈øons; „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and repealing of Lawes, to the erecting and
aboli≈øhing of Offices and Courts, to the appointing, removing and calling to account Magi≈øtrates, and Officers, of all degrees; to the making War and peace, to the treating with forreigne States: And generally, to what≈øoever is not expre≈øly, or implyedly re≈øerved by the repre≈øented to them≈øelves.

list.item: 1. THat matters of Religion, and the wayes of Gods Wor≈øhip, are not at all intru≈øted by us to any humane power becau≈øe therein we cannot remit or exceed a tittle of what our Con≈øciences dictate to be the mind of God, without wilfull ≈øin: neverthele≈ø≈øe the publike way of in≈øtructing the Nation (≈øo it be not compul≈øive) is referred to their di≈øeretion.

2. That the matter of impre≈øting and con≈øtraining any of us to ≈øerve in the wars, is again≈øt our freedome; and therefore we do not allow it in our Repre≈øentatives; the rather, becau≈øe money (the ≈øinews of war) being alwayes at their di≈øpo≈øall, they can never want numbers of men apt enough to engage in any ju≈øt cau≈øe.

3. That after the di≈ø≈øolution of this pre≈øent Parliament, no per≈øon be at any time que≈øtioned for any thing ≈øaid or done, in reference to the late publike differences, otherwi≈øe then in execution of the Judgments of the pre≈øent Repre≈øentatives, or Hou≈øe of Commons.

4. That in all Lawes made, or to be made, every per≈øon may bee bound alike, and that no Tenure, E≈øtate, Charter Degree, Birth, or place, do confer any exemption from the ordinary Cour≈øe of Legall proccedings, whereunto others are ≈øubjected.
5. That as the Lawes ought to be equall ≈øo they mu≈øt be good & not evidently de≈øtructive to the ≈øafety and well-being of the People.

div.p: THe≈øe things we declare to be our native Rights, and therefore are agreed and re≈øolved to maintaine them with our utmo≈øt po≈ø≈øibilities, again≈øt all oppo≈øition what≈øoever being compelled thereunto not only by the examples of our Ance≈øtors who≈øe bloud was often ≈øpent in vain for the recovery of their Freedomes, ≈øuffering them≈øelves through fraudulent Accommodations, to be ≈øtill deluded of the fruit of their Victories, but al≈øo by our own wofull experience, who having long expected, and dearly earned the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the≈øe certain rules of Government, are yet made to depend for the ≈øettlement of our Peace and freedome, upon him that intended our bondage, and brought a cruell Warre upon us.

div.head: To the ≈øupreame Authority of this Nation, the Commons of England in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled.
The Petition of tho≈øe who≈øe Names are ≈øub≈øcribed, in behalfe of them ≈øelve≈ø, and all the free-born people of England.
div.p: THat we are exceedingly amazed at your Vote upon our Petition, and Agreement, and cannot but compare the ≈øame to the proceedings of the Hou≈øe vpon our Petition prepared for his Excellencie, or upon the large and mo≈øt ju≈øt Petition. Which was voted to be burnt by the common Hangman.

That your di≈øclaiming of us herein, and your ≈øo ≈øpeedy pro≈øecution of an accommodation with the King (who ≈øought our bondage and ruine ≈øo long as he was able) before the liberties of the people are cl ‚Ä¢ ered, and ≈øetled, or the Rights of the Army provided or ≈øecured, give us too much cau≈øe to feare, the ≈øame influences in the Hou≈øe, as lately voted the disbanding of the Army, u≈øurped a Parliament Authority, voted a new Warre; and the Kings coming to London upon dangerous tearmes.

That we are ≈øo confident, of the equity of our Agreement, and ju≈øtne≈ø≈øe of our Petition, and ≈øo tender of the ju≈øt Authority of this Honourable Hou≈øe, that we are con≈øtrained again to intreat your ≈øecond Review of both; and that you will be ≈øo mindfull of your owne and the Armies Declarations, as to ≈øu≈øpend all thoughts of accommodation with the King, vntill tho≈øe Foundations of common Freedome, wherein the good of all men is included, bee firmly ≈øetled, it bring impo≈ø≈øible for us, or any free-born Engli≈øhmen, who rightly under≈øtand their Liberties, ever to for≈øake, or decline the ≈øame.

And wee dos further mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øire all ≈øuch worthy Members of this Honourable Hou≈øe, as doe yet remember their duty to their Native Country, not to let flip this opportunity of joyning with us in this Agreement for their redemption and ours, out of the hands of our proud, cruell, and treacherous Enemies, that we may live or dye together, in the vindication of our Native-Freedome.

closer.signed: Sub≈øcribed unto by the afore≈øaid Agents of the re≈øpective Regiments.
